image.caption: Image courtesy of the Carl Albert Center Congressional Archives

profileText: (Brother of Max Schwabe), a Representative from Oklahoma; born in Arthur, Vernon County, Mo., July 26, 1886; attended the country and town schools of Pettis County, Mo., and Sedalia (Mo.) High School; in 1910 was graduated from the law department of the University of Missouri at Columbia; was admitted to the bar the same year and commenced practice in Columbia, Mo.; moved to Nowata, Okla., in 1911 and continued the practice of law; mayor of Nowata, Okla., in 1913 and 1914; member of the Nowata Board of Education 1918-1922; member of the State house of representatives from Nowata County 1918-1922, serving as speaker in 1921 and 1922; moved to Tulsa, Okla., in 1922 and continued the practice of law; chairman of the Republican county committee of Tulsa County, Okla., 1928-1936; delegate to all Republican State conventions after 1912 and to the Republican National Convention in 1936; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-ninth and Eightieth Congresses (January 3, 1945-January 3, 1949); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1948 to the Eighty-first Congress; elected to the Eighty-second Congress and served from January 3, 1951, until his death in Alexandria, Va., April 2, 1952; interment in Memorial Park Cemetery, Tulsa, Okla.

researchRecord.name: 1921-1952, 33 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of George Schwabe consist of personal correspondence, general correspondence, subject files, departmental files, legislative files, committee files, constituent cases, photographs, and newspaper clippings. The topics covered in the papers include flood control and agriculture (particularly in Oklahoma), Indian affairs legislation, civil service, veterans, and the Office of Price Controls. Committee files include the following topics: appropriations for the 80th Congress and appropriations for agriculture, soil conservation, rural electrification, Department of the Interior, Indian affairs and services, vocational education, and health services. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: In the George Howard Wilson Papers, 1933-1974, 38 cubic feet.
